results.headline: Rappers of Old, Through a Lens of History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer

results.summary_short: “Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer” pays tribute to a New York chronicler and his subjects, especially hip-hop artists of the 1980s.

results.headline: Being on the Rebound Never Felt So Good

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Spectacular Now

results.summary_short: James Ponsoldt’s new film, “The Spectacular Now,” is a tale of a teenager and the speed bumps at the end of high school.

results.headline: Australia’s ’70s Surfer Culture, Poised to Go Global

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drift

results.summary_short: In “Drift,” two brothers struggle to set up a business selling homemade surfing gear in an isolated coastal town.

results.headline: Two Good Guys (or So They Seem) Behaving Badly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 Guns

results.summary_short: The Baltasar Kormakur buddy film “2 Guns” turns on a pair of seemingly bad guys who may be good, out to rob a drug cartel’s money from a bank.

results.headline: Careful, Zombies: Granddad Lived Through the Blitz

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cockneys Vs. Zombies

results.summary_short: In “Cockneys vs. Zombies,” a nursing home and an East London way of life are threatened by a zombie takeover.

results.headline: A Wedding Turned Nightmare (but Oh, the Video!)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breakup at a Wedding

results.summary_short: In “Breakup at a Wedding,” a bride gets cold feet, but the couple decide to go through with the ceremony anyway.

results.headline: Catskills Comedy Era Is the Focus of Documentary

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When Comedy Went To School

results.summary_short: Jerry Stiller, Jerry Lewis, Jackie Mason and other headliners are featured in “When Comedy Went to School,” a documentary about the Catskills comedy circuit.

results.headline: Blue-Hued Stepparents Enjoy Some Redemption

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Smurfs 2

results.summary_short: Smurf essence is the elusive goal in “The Smurfs 2.”

results.headline: Pride Stays, Even After the Fall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue Jasmine

results.summary_short: Cate Blanchett plays a wealthy woman who has lost her money and her bearings in “Blue Jasmine,” directed by Woody Allen.

results.headline: Some Things You Can’t Learn From a Book

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The To Do List

results.summary_short: In “The To Do List,” Aubrey Plaza plays a smart and driven high school graduate who decides that she has been missing something and sets out to lose her virginity.

results.headline: They’ll Follow Their Pal to the Bitter, Senseless End

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wasteland

results.summary_short: Rowan Athale’s “Wasteland” takes viewers on a tour of a hopeless youth in the north of England before turning into a crime caper.

results.headline: Angst-Ridden Artist on a Mysterious Mission

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Time Being

results.summary_short: “The Time Being,” with Frank Langella as a dying eccentric, doesn’t really go anywhere, but provides pretty pictures along the way.

results.headline: Those Female Astronauts, Always Being Impregnated by Aliens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stranded

results.summary_short: “Stranded,” about a lunar base invaded by nonhuman visitors, has decent acting but awfully familiar elements.

results.headline: Underwater Dream, Stymied by Drugs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Tide

results.summary_short: Dino J. Gallina’s M.F.A. project, “Red Tide” features unsympathetic characters engaged in uninteresting pursuits.

results.headline: Claws and Heart Get a Workout in Japan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wolverine

results.summary_short: Hugh Jackman’s ageless Wolverine returns to the screen, this time in the Land of the Rising Sun.

results.headline: Rich American Girl Meets Poor Peruvian Boy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Postales

results.summary_short: In Josh Hyde’s “Postales,” a 12-year-old visiting Peru makes a connection with a young postcard seller.

results.headline: He’s Just a Cave Man in a Modern World
results.display_title: Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man

results.summary_short: In “Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man,” a Homo neanderthalensis is in danger of being exploited for a quick buck.

results.headline: Something Unpleasant Behind Enemy Lines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frankenstein's Army

results.summary_short: “Frankenstein’s Army,” directed by Richard Raaphorst, has a plethora of unsettling — and refreshingly nondigital — zombie robots.

results.headline: Running on Illegal Fuel and Savage Zeal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drug War

results.summary_short: The Hong Kong director Johnnie To filmed his high-velocity tale of bad guys and good in China, with no evident softening of unsettling action.

results.headline: Joking About Murder Can Have Consequences

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breaking the Girls

results.summary_short: In Jamie Babbit’s “Breaking the Girls,” two friends fantasize about offing their enemies, but one turns out to be serious.
